text:
I have always been excited about
trying to start something new.

Life is really short and
I see entrepreneurship

as being the best platform
to make dreams happen.

Ultimately, it was just
like burning desire to help.

My mom was a real estate
agent for 14 years.

That's something that I always
wanted to do in my life,

creating a company in
the real estate space.

My co-founder and I were
college basketball teammates.

There was often a difficulty
in balancing school and sport

while in college,
and so we wanted

to start a program that
would help future athletes do
all of that successfully.

My brother was diagnosed with
Duchenne muscular dystrophy
when he was three.

You go from being on
the sidelines to wanting

to do more, so we're working
on a new approach that

would actually restore
significant muscle function.

It's my first time
founding a company,

but it is a completely
different feeling

to take on big problems
and all of the uncertainty.

The day to day of
an entrepreneur
is completely unpredictable.

One day you're
fundraising, one day you're

pitching to customers,
another day you're

working with your team
on execution issues.

You get full ownership
over your work

and that means the small and
annoying things, but also
the big and incredible things.

You have to decide
everything for yourself.

You can spend hours
trying to figure out

whether line 17 on your tax
return is your gross assets

or you net assets and only
you can figure that out.

And I'm constantly
checking in to see, oh,

have people gone
on to the topic?
Are they reacting to it?

Are people talking about
this on our social channels?

There's so much going
on as an entrepreneur.

The pitch is probably the
most important part of it

because you can
have the best idea,

but the presentation is
your moment of truth.

Pitching is trying to fit
your whole body in a matchbox.

You've got an amazing
idea and while you

could go on and on
about it for hours,

you only have a
couple of minutes.

I'm still feeling like extremely
energized from just hearing

an outsider say, hey
this sounds very exciting
and it feels like a good idea.

The one defining characteristic
of entrepreneurs is tenacity.
Nothing gets them down.
And there's no safety net.

I think you have to have a
very high appetite for risk.

I think of it like juggling
like about 15 balloons all
at the same time.

So you have to really
believe in a problem
that you're trying to solve.
Super cool.

Like this is a really,
really interesting idea.

It's always really good
to get positive feedback.

I try not to let bad
thoughts in my head
because it's a long road ahead.

It's relatively
easy to be motivated
when things are going well.

It's not that easy, though,
when you don't get that client
or you don't sign that contract.

There are days when
we put a topic up

that nobody is
interested in reading

or where we'll test a new
feature that completely bombs.

We've entered a
really complex space

with no clear solution for
solving the broader skills gap

problem and we've run
into a bunch of walls.

You want to be building
something that's improbable,
not something that's impossible.

My first meeting was
with a venture capitalist

who I was just going
to for feedback

and they basically told me
that there was no business

model here, but then
later that day, I

met another venture capitalist
who totally understood
where I was coming from.

By the end of the
conversation, we'd

come to an iteration of
the business model that
made even more sense.

I've never seen anyone
get more excited than Matt

after getting off of a
potential customer call
and it going well.

And so that's sort
of what sustains us.
Someone says, hey.
You guys are on the right track.

Every single person
we'd spoke to about it

said I've been looking
for this for so long.
Where were you a month ago?
I felt it.

That's why I started
it, is because it's

a business that I wanted to
exist and it didn't exist.

It's incredibly cool to look
back and think none of this

would have happened if we as
a team hadn't put in the hours
to make it happen.

I think we've make a lot
progress in the last few weeks,

but I'm not satisfied
with the pace.
I want to do more faster.

I'm happier now than I've
really ever been in a long time.

I'm most excited
about so many things.
It's something I'm hooked on.
No more talking.
It's actually making it happen.
